lines.text: I'd say she's perfect. I've been in space for six months and she looks perfect to me.
It'll be much less terrifying if you just come to me.
I'll do just that.

[snatches camera from photographer, exposes film then hands it back]
Sorry!
Now she has clothes.
It was the hardest thing I ever did.
We understand. It must have taken great courage to try and...
No, you don't understand. Part of me didn't want to leave. She killed all my friends and I still didn't want to leave. Leaving her was the hardest thing I ever did.
Don't worry. A naked girl is not going to get out of this complex.

I mean, in a sense we're all vampires. We drain energy from other life forms. The difference is one of degree. That girl was no girl. She's totally alien to this planet and our life form... and totally dangerous.
It was two hours ago that the guard was attacked. I wouldn't be at all surprised if we're seeing a pattern here.
Colonel, take it from the beginning. Assume we know nothing... which is understating the matter.

She's resisting. I'm going to have to force her to tell me. Despite appearances, this women is a masochist. An extreme masochist. She wants me to force the name out of her. She wants me to hurt her. I can see the images in her mind. You want to stay? Otherwise wait outside!
Not at all. I'm a natural voyeur.
You mean life after death?
Yes.
Is there?
What?
Life after death?
Do you really want to know?
No.
Well, to answer your question, yes...

[looking at a shrivelled corpse]
And this was murder, you say?
The web of destiny carries your blood and soul back to the genesis of my lifeform.
But I understand your real interest is...
Death, Colonel Caine, correct. Thanatology's the name for it. Death for you, Colonel, is a bureaucratic problem. Who did it. When, why did they do it. A problem to be solved, am I correct?
And for you?
Well, I'm fascinated by death itself. What happens as we die, when we die. What happens after we die.
Which one of you is Doctor Bukovsky?
I am.
I'm Colonel Caine.
From the SAS?
Gentleman, that last remark is not for publication. This is a D notice situation.
Supposing you're right about all of this. What about that ship up there. What's it doing?
We can't know that. But we've got to assume the worst.

The girl he picked up was a nurse named Ellen. As you say, Ellen something or other. He doesn't know her other name, but he dropped her off at Thurlstone Hospital after spending the afternoon with her. He was very reluctant to talk about it. The man's totally exhausted.
I am the feminine in your mind, Carlsen.
Sir, while you were with the PM, I had a call from base operations. The city is under martial law. We've been placed under NATO command.
NATO!
She's totally dangerous.
[last lines]
Here I go.
Also, the Churchill's escape pod is missing.
What's that mean, did someone escape?
Um... how do you know she's still inside Armstrong? What's to prevent her from moving to someone else?
She's trapped. I can feel that.
Are you sure?
No.
Tell me again how the girl over powered you.
She... was the most overwhelmingly feminine presence I have ever encountered. I was drawn to her on a level...
Was it sexual?
Yes. Overwhelmingly so, and horrible. Loss of control.

[Derebridge and Carlsen are observing the spaceship]
What you gonna do?
We want in. We only gonna get one chance, Derebridge. That thing won't be back for another 76 years. We'll both be dead. We have to take a look now.
She's not human she's an alien, she'll destroy you!
She's destroyed worlds...

[on the radio, referring to the bats floating inside the spaceship]
Churchill, there must be hundreds of them.
Thousands. Dead, I hope.

[looking at the rests of the humanoids]
At what appears these two are no longer dangerous.
Do as he says Kelly. Also, I want the two other bodies that were shot, The males. Collect the pieces and watch them. Get me the home secretary on the line now!
Miss Haversham! Miss Haversham!
